Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 06:14PM dawn31337 wrote: Everyone is different, but even my doctors agree, attitude is 50% of this.  A good attitude may not prevent you from being sick, but a bad one will definitely bring it on.  It will all be over before you know it.  In 4 weeks I get my new boobs!
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 12:39PM dawn31337 wrote: I learned a long time ago the only person you can really depend upon is yourself.  I'm sorry you are learning this at such a bad time.  Expecting someone who isn't your family or spouse for financial assistance is somewhat naive. After 2 1/2 years of dating, I'm sure you talked about your future at some point.  If it was right for both of you, you'd either be living together now, or engaged, or married.   I think you are rightfully angry you got cancer, and he probably is too.   If you thought he was a decent guy before, maybe he still is, but neither of you are dealing with this well.  If you are angry about no gas in the truck, I'm sure today isn't the first time a little thing has bothered you.  Maybe your relationship just isn't strong enough for something this stressful, and it's time to let go.   Chemo didn't make me nasty, or even sick; it made me tired.   Talk to someone about your anger (about both your illness and your relationship), you will make it through treatment a lot better if you de-stress as much as you can.  This is a mind f$#% and if you expect the worst, that's exactly what you'll get.   Getting chemo by yourself is no big deal.  You sit in a chair and get an IV.  That's it.  I brought my iPod and took a nap.  It is medicine.  Not to trivialize, but is he there if you have the flu? Even people on these boards who have had issues with SE say it is like the flu.  You aren't going to die.  Best of luck to you.  There are many people who went through this alone.
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 07:08PM dawn31337 wrote: I had a double mastectomy 2 weeks ago, with TEs.  I bought some pretty cami's from VS and Neiman Marcus for 'date nights' and some cami body shapers from JCP that are kind of hard to get in and out of, but they are pretty.  I swear I feel better when I'm in something pretty rather than that nasty blood stained surgical bra.  I look really good under the cami's.  You shouldn't have the drains for too long.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 09:11PM dawn31337 wrote: Marie, you look awesome! I also got prenatal vitamins and have been taking them hit or miss.  I did have long hair and nails when I was pregnant.  No harm, no foul, you just pee away excess vitamins.  Thank goodness I don't need Tamoxifen, or I would probably forget to take that every day too. My medical staff basically said you have to wait for the hair to grow back, and I specifically asked about Rogaine.   I did buy some Biotene (B7) today because I'm impatient (as we all are).  I got the 5000 mcg kind.  Why just do something when you can do something to excess? :)  Story of my life.   Seriously, does anyone have a recommendation about how much to take?  Again, you just pee away what's not needed, so I can't see any harm in extra.  I used to ask my kids' pediatrician about vitamins, and he said if I want to make their urine rich, give them vitamins.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 09:19PM dawn31337 wrote: Husker, if you haven't done it, look into the Look Good Feel Better class.  You get some nice cosmetics, and they give you good tips.  It should be free in your area.  Warning!  you get a grab bag of high end and grocery store cosmetics.  The high end stuff is a lot better :)  Like when I got my first Dolce & Gabbana suit, wow, you can never go back.

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 11:29AM dawn31337 wrote: FL Warrior - the first color I tried was Natural Instincts, but I found it didn't cover so well.  I have been using Revlon ColorSilk, it is ammonia free, cheap, and seems to work well.  It was even rated #1 by Good Housekeeping, and it is like $3.50 a box.  My stylist agreed I should use something ammonia free, and that there isn't really any sense in having him color it for now.  Plus, all the professional stuff has ammonia in it - at his shop anyway.  He said to be as kind to my hair as possible for the first year. Henna, in my opinion, is a PITA, but all do it yourself hair color is to some extent.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 08:17PM dawn31337 wrote: As for texture, I always had dark brown curly hair.  I have to say the texture and color are pretty much the same (maybe a few more greys..shhhh!!!).  You lucky girls with straight or wavy hair may see a difference of texture, but I don't.  It doesn't seem any curlier than usual, except that it is short.  Longer curly hair weighs itself out and it looks straighter.  Short curly hair takes forever to look long. They make fantastic products now for curly hair to look nice curly, or to straighten and smooth. Matrix products are great for straight look, but I dislike the smell.  CHI is good too.  Garnier Fructis straight formula isn't bad either.  Curls Rock is good for curly styles.   I have also been using Redken 06, but not everyday, as I feel like I have helmet head. In the mid 70s I had an "afro" and I am caucasian.  It was in style then, and the longer my hair gets, the more it looks like that.  My hair is still too short to blow dry straight without making a frizzy mess, and my darling daughter broke my Sedu.   My stylist did say to take it easy on the hair with color, chemicals, and heat for the first year.  I do use a mini flat iron on my bangs though.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 09:53PM dawn31337 wrote: I kept my nails painted the whole time and only had an issue with one wee-wee-wee-all-the-way-home toe, and it was only purple on the bottom.  It never fell off and is the right color growing under the purple now.  The cosmetician at the Look Good Feel Better class said it was better to keep the nails polished because they lose less moisture.  That's not why I kept doing the polish, but I didn't have issues.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 10:52PM dawn31337 wrote: Wow, that sucks Husker.  My class was great.  I even got to be the model, lol because i had no hair.  I got a nasty wig from there.  I speak my mind and i probably offended the cosmetologist there, but that wig was fugly!!  she did make it look better though.  as simple as hair combing is, those who are trained are definitely a lot better at it.  i think you did get a dud leader!!!  hope you at least got good stuff.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 08:53AM dawn31337 wrote: I had DD AC every other week for 4 treatments.  Like many of you, it started coming out at maybe day 12, and I shaved it off.  I felt I had control of losing my hair by doing that, plus less mess. Then I had DD Taxol every other week for 4 treatments.  I started getting peach fuzz probably by week 3, and that longer clear fuzz as time went on. I started taking Biotin 3 weeks after my last chemo, and I swear it accelerates growth, but I am not sure it is working on my head.  I had lost every lash and every brow hair.  The lashes started coming in first, and suddenly I have a LOT of clear brow hair.  It is gradually getting darker.  I also had a lot of sudden clear upper lip hair, and my leg and pubic hair seemed to have grown overnight. The facial hair is a little disturbing, so I'm cutting back on the biotin.  It's not like I should shave or anything, but still!  Maybe I just got used to being hairless.  Sunflower, I have to say I was in hysterics reading about your pirate look!!  Sorry about the ingrown lash, that must have hurt.  On Taxol I would get tiny styes and my eyes were very watery. I probably rubbed all my lashes out. For those of you considering henna, if you ever want to use chemical dyes again, I believe you have to let the henna treated hair grow out and get it cut off.   Right now I am hoping for any bit of length at all, and don't want to lose any of it!!  I got Natural Instincts semi permanent color to try this weekend.  I don't have enough hair to justify a trip to the salon, and this stuff evidently washes out after 28 shampoos.  Hopefully I won't look like Ronald McDonald.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 05:35PM dawn31337 wrote: Nancy, I think the best flatirons are Sedu, Amika and FHI.  They are all expensive and get very hot. Guess what the F in FHI stands for!  I had crazy curly hair before chemo, so far it is straight now, but only about an inch long.  The sleek hair products help with straightening, and be sure to condition and use some kind of barrier like BioSilk or CHI, or you will fry your hair.  I've been flatironing mine for eons, but will need to get a small one so I don't burn my scalp.  These irons get to like 400, but you can set them lower. 2nd Natural Instincts update - I've washed my hair 4x and most of it washed out.  You can see the greys again.  Not sure if it's the product or chemo hair.  Will try the permanent root touch up stuff this weekend as I still can't justify the salon. I am not a costume jewelry fan, and will only wear "real," but Lia Sophia really does have some pretty stuff.  It is one of those home party things, and they have great deals for hostesses.  My daughter had a party before her prom, and I think it was something like buy one get 2 free, plus very good discounts based on sales.  I think all their stuff has a lifetime guarantee.  One of her friends is having a party this weekend.  They also have a catalog online.  Brighton also has really pretty things, I love their shoes and handbags. LOL, also a Biotin update.  I was saying only I could see the facial hair.....wrong.  I went to dinner with my daughter and she said, "wow, does that biotin make the hair grow on your face too?"  Cut it close with scissors today!  :)   Just my experience, but be warned!  Don't worry though, nothing scissors can't fix.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 07:12PM dawn31337 wrote: Watch out for the Biotin, I am becoming convinced it causes me to grow excessive facial hair. Nothing I can't take care of with a pair of scissors, but my conclusion is that's definitely what's causing it.  I stopped taking it for a couple weeks, then started again.  I am hairy again now.  I am not positive the hair on my head grows any faster, but it certainly helps with face, legs, and pubies.  :( The Garnier Fructis products are good for curly hair.  I always had curly hair and found them to work pretty well.  Also the Matrix products but I hated the smell.  If you want to go curly, Curls Rock is good.  I love the Sedu flatirons.    Have any of you had issues with nails?  I kept mine polished the whole time, but my big and pinkie toe on the right could easily be pulled off.  I also broke my thumbnails very low, but they are growing pretty well.  My toenails seem to grow slowly, so if I lose my big toenail, I swear it would take a year to grow back...and this is now sandal weather!  Does anyone know what's underneath?  I'll leave them attached for as long as I can, but I go to the beach a lot and am now worried about the sand.  LOL I should find something more important to worry about!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 06:04PM dawn31337 wrote: Let me tell you all a funny story.  I am 7 weeks PFC, had exchange surgery last week (boobs look and feel great) and have been taking 5000 mcg of Biotin a day.  Not sure if the hair on my head is growing any faster, but I have to tell you I look like a pre-pubescent Santa Claus.  The facial hair is fine and light like it always was, but maybe I just don't remember having hair!  My lashes have been growing back, and they look pretty decent.  My brows are growing like wildfire now, but the hair itself is still light.  The hair on my head is between 3/4 and 1", mostly brown, but I will be coloring it this weekend.  I have a bike trip next weekend and I was hoping for longer hair.  Maybe the color will give it that appearance.  I got Natural Instincts that washes out, because I'm afraid of freakish dark hair.  One of the brands I looked at said not to use it if you had a tattoo (more allergic reactions), what a riot!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2011 08:35PM dawn31337 wrote: Sara, you look beautiful!! I was also lucky and did chemo over the winter.  I work knit caps around the house and to bed and have several pretty wigs.  I'm lucky and work from home.  I have maybe 1" of hair and am going topless at home now that it's warm, and have been wearing do rags at like the grocery store, but still wear wigs if I go "out".  Bonny, that would piss me off too, but you're right.  People who don't know probably didn't know the difference.  Especially men!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 08:08PM dawn31337 wrote: Husker, I waited 2 or 3 weeks after chemo to start the biotin.  I hadn't taken it before and I felt better letting my body detox from the chemo first.  My hair started growing back with the clear fuzz during Taxol.  I should also mention i'm triple negative, so no other meds for me.  I am not sure if Tamoxifen or the HER2+ stuff inhibits hair growth or not.  I also use head & shoulders shampoo because i read somewhere dandruff shampoo helps with the scalp.  LOL, i just bought a trial size and I have only used about half of it!!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 08:38PM dawn31337 wrote: Carrol, that's horrible!!  I found out about the cold caps before I started chemo, but I thought the price was ridiculous, and I just couldn't justify it, plus it sounded like a total PITA.  Also my oncologist thought constricting the blood flow in the scalp wasn't a good thing, but I expected that answer.  If they had been affordable or if my cancer center had the freezers I probably would have done it. So the wigs were fun for a while, and now I have no split ends.  I can get showered and dressed to go out in < 15 minutes.  There is always a silver lining!

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 11:43PM dawn31337 wrote: The Matrix sleek products were good on my non-chemo-induced curly hair.  I didn't care for the smell though.  Garnier Fructris also had decent products, and they also had some treatment that lasted a few weeks.  It's been a while so I don't remember what it was called.  CHI really also worked for me, but my hair was greasy or some condition I didn't care for after using it.  Maybe knotty. I used to dry my hair using a round brush, then I used a flatiron.  Get a good one (sedu, fhi) that gets nice and hot, and you can beat the humidity.  Use a barrier product like the Redken liquid silk stuff to protect your hair, or you can burn it easily.  I have a dryer that has a round brush attached to it.  I'm thinking if you can figure out what I'm talking about, that might be a good tool for you curly haired girls to try.  If you are embracing your curls, try Curls Rock products in turquoise bottles.    On another positive hair note, I cut myself shaving my legs today, LOL!  What memories!!!  Hurt like hell, but at least I'm growing hair!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 15, 2011 07:35PM - edited May 15, 2011 07:42PM by dawn31337 Thanks Scrabblelady!  I love scrabble too.  I live maybe 15 min from Caravel.  My kids wanted to go there. As for the cancer awareness....do any of you go to say the grocery store and they ask you if you want to contribute?  I feel I have already contributed with my life.  My dollars are paying for my deductibles and copays.  That kinds sucks.    I am luckier than most, in that I have worked full time during treatment, but I work from home. Not many of my co-workers know I have been through cancer treatment.  Last time I worked with them in a group setting was in February, and I wore a wig.  Now I have a big install on June 26.  I hope I can grow more hair in the next 6 weeks.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 08:48PM dawn31337 wrote: Goldie, I always had curly hair, and maybe when mine grows back it will be less so.  They make much better products these days.  The Sedu flatirons are the bomb, and CHI and Garnier shampoos/conditioners in the sleek and smooth formulas are good.  Matrix is also really good, but I hated the fragrance.  I'm not sure how the ultra hot flatirons are on chemo hair though, make sure you use a product for heat or you may have damage.  For when you want curly hair, try Curls Rock in a turquoise bottle - helps with the frizz.   It's been so long since I've done my hair it's funny telling anyone these tips!

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 06:19PM dawn31337 wrote: I have been taking Biotin for 1 week.  I am 4 weeks PFC, and my hair started with the colorless fuzz while I was on Taxol.   Maybe it is coincidence, but I *swear* my hair has grown faster over the past week while using the Biotin.  I am taking 5000 mcg a day.  It seems longer, and my head definitely has more dark hair; it is about 1/2 long on average.  And I got the shock of shocks today - after my shower today I noticed 1/2" of hair on my legs.  I know it doesn't make sense that it grew that much in a week, but I swear last time I checked there was just stubble.   Now if it would just help my eyebrows grow!!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 08:18PM dawn31337 wrote: Lago, I rub my head all the time, it just feels good to have *some* hair!  :)
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 08:32PM dawn31337 wrote: Also, I don't think I have any more wrinkles, but I think the "severe" hair style we're stuck with for now accentuates our shortfalls.  I think I look fabulous in my wigs!  I have been using night cream after my LGFB class.  I did some research and saw Avon Anew was rated pretty high.  I think it is doing the trick, but it is really thick, kinda greasy, and very strong smelling.  The fragrance is nice enough, but really overwhelming.  All in all, I think the product seems to do what it says. I got a whole full size set with day and night cream, cleanser, and eye cream on eBay for about $50 to try it out.  When it's gone I'll probably switch to Lancome.  I got some small sizes as a bonus when buying other stuff, and I like the fragrance better.  Of course it is probably 3x the price.  I got spoiled with the LGFB cosmetics. I think the worst part is the eyebrows.  I've gotten good at drawing them on, and thanks to Biotin (i think!) mine are now growing back, but the pigment in them is taking time.  My lashes definitely grew better, and they're definitely longer than 1/4" now.  Oddly enough the last of my arm hair was gone about 2 weeks ago.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 11:02AM dawn31337 wrote: Natural Instincts update:  I tried to get the same color as my own hair, and overall it looks good, but I had 2 patches of grey it didn't cover well.  One is a quarter sized patch to the right of the top of my head.  I guess it is a little darker, but you can still see it.  I was hoping to have 'virgin' hair for a while and that's why I chose the semi-permanent.  If you have some greys here and there, it covers/blends fine, but the patches not so much.  Should have followed my first instinct and gotten the permanent root touch up stuff.  I used maybe 1/4 of the full sized semi-permanent stuff and put it on pretty thick. Lavogt - most of my hair fell out after I shaved it.  When the peach fuzz started coming in I left it alone.   I had my chemo over the winter and wore knit caps around the house.  The peach fuzz was my hair coming back in.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 08:40PM dawn31337 wrote: Lago, only my pinkie toe turned purple, but my big toe is now broken halfway across maybe 1/4" from the cuticle.  The pinkie toe didn't break, and none of them really turned gross, but I could definitely pull them off.  My fingernails are mostly fine.  My thumbs broke pretty far down, but I kept them glued for as long as I could, and now they're not broken to the quick.  I know I'm going to have a problem with the one big toe.  Did yours actually come off? LOL I'm brave enough to go topless but I'm worrying about a toenail.  This sh!t makes you nuts, doesn't it??  :)

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 09:56PM dawn31337 wrote: @LtotheK  I was 48, but still young.  Hell, I'm still young.  I work from home and go to the office literally every 12-18 months for installs.  My boss's boss commented on my short hair last time I was in.  I didn't make my situation public except for my closest co-workers.  I just took off on chemo days.  I am the luckiest girl in the world I was able to do that.   I just had my second trim last week.  I look exactly like my mother.....she had stage IV and died 24 months later, just as expected.  I am not sure of how I feel seeing her staring right back at me.  I am an only child, and she waited until she was dying until she saw a doctor.  It is a total brain freeze for me.  I feel sorry for her because she was so scared, but I resent her for leaving me alone. What a FU'd disease.

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 08:36PM dawn31337 wrote: I got my first haircut today!!  Kind of a Pixie cut, with Redken #6 to take advantage of my curls (which I always had).  I rode my motorcycle there so it got messed up right away, but it was a good feeling!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2011 08:27PM dawn31337 wrote: Tappy, I agree with bdavis, it is a personal choice.  When mine started falling out I shaved it to maybe 1/4".  I felt I had control, and I didn't have a mess.  It's gonna fall out anyway.  bdavis probaby had a better idea.  I thought shaving my head was much more emotional than losing the titties.  The good news is, it grows back pretty fast really.  I am 8 months out and have had 2 trims. I color it with Revlon Colorsoft (cheap and it lasts...I am not blonde and can't justify a $$$ salon color yet). It isn't even close to the hair I had, but it looks like I might have chosen this style. People compliment me on it, but it is still too short for my taste.  The best thing I can say, is when I ride my Harley it doesn't get tangled up.  That is a win.

Posts.Title: Unilateral or Bilateral txkari cinnamonsmiles

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 08:26PM dawn31337 wrote: First, kill the caps lock.  :) Second, ask your oncologist to prescribe Atavan or something for you.  Your additional stress won't help your recovery!   It will just take the edge off and help you sleep.  You're not going to get strung out on it, and don't let a prescription think you can't handle this alone.  You need to do whatever it takes to get through this.  Attitude is everything!  My first chemo I bit the nurse's head off because they were late for my appointment.  Honestly, I found acupuncture helped.  It sounds crazy, but I have 2 friends with constant pain who swear by it. I found it did help me relax.  Best of luck to you!!!!
Posts.Title: EMOTIONAL WRECK Blayze7 mdg

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 10:55PM dawn31337 wrote: Mine was a month.  Count on a year going through this crap, from surgery to chemo to reconstruction.  A year at best.  I can give you a project plan (mpp) if anyone needs one.  I did EVERYTHING I could do to make it less than a year.  For some of you it will work, for me it didn't. In the grand scheme of things though one year isn't a make or break thing.  For that one year, you only go through the rotten for < 2 months.  So 83% of the time, you will feel fine.  That's a win.
Posts.Title: how long between diagnosis and surgery? Mallory107 withlove

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 07:53PM dawn31337 wrote: Hi LovingMother, My BLM was an easy decision for me to make.  It was my first gut reaction for a silly reason - I'd get to have bigger boobs!  My 2nd thought was go for the lumpectomy and deal with mastectomy later if need be....but i really thought it through, and with lumpectomy you always get rads, boobs could be uneven, etc., and it runs in my family, so I went with my gut and got BLM.   It was the easiest surgery I ever had.  I had skin sparing on the cancer side (and have no nipple) and nipple sparing on the good side.  I had immediate reconstruction with tissue expanders.  Other than feeling tight across my chest, there really was no pain, because they cut all the nerves.  The fills aren't bad, and the bigger they get, the better they seem to feel.  I may have a higher tolerance to pain than most, but this really hasn't been a big deal.  I had my BLM on Friday and was back to work Monday (caveat is that i have a desk job at home, but I do work a full time week).  Sleeping was tough at first, and the drains were more gross than annoying.  I'm pretty much filled to the max now and the boob with the nipple looks really pretty.  I just got done AC today (YAY) and have 4 more dd T and should finish chemo end of Feb.  AC was a breeze.  Hoping T will be as well.  Should switch to silicone implants in April and get a nipple and tattoo after that. I had terrible migranes as a kid, and I swear they went away after i started birth control pills or maybe smoking pot.  I have done neither in recent history because pot just makes me stupid, and i had my tubes tied 19 years ago.  2 dear friends SWEAR by acupuncture (one for migranes), so I've been doing it before chemo treatments.  Something has clearly worked.  My only SE is weepy eyes, and of course baldness, but my therapist says hair grows back faster with continued acupuncture.  Anyway, you may want to consider that for your headaches and also to help control your SE.  It doesn't hurt, and you leave feeling very relaxed.   The hardest part for me has been the unknown.  I did the BLM because BC runs in my family (turns out i am BRCA1 and 2 negative), but even though this has not been an ordeal for me, I definitely don't want to go through it again.  My cousin had the lumpectomy and a couple of revisions.  You still lose the hair, and you have rads to deal with too.  With the Mx you don't have rads and that was part of my decision.  I just want to get this over with.  I have no breast tissue left, so in my mind, there's little chance of it coming back (Dr said 98% chance of NOT coming back, but it could show up in the incisions - that beats the sh!t of having a whole other boob for it to fester in). Beat of luck to you.  It really isn't that bad, but I do have a MS Project Plan with my end date, and I am now 54% complete!!!!  I probably have Scarlett O'Hara Syndrome, but I try not to read negative posts, I KNOW I will beat this, and I truly believe tomorrow will be a better day.  Expect the best and you sometimes get it.  Expect the worst and you get what you expect.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 07:20PM dawn31337 wrote: Hi Esther, You're going through the worst of this right now.  It is all a shock when it starts, but the treatment isn't as bad as you think it is.  I chose to be very aggressive with my treatment and had BLM and chemo. Neither were hard.  I was never in real pain, and was never really sick, and worked the whole time.  Get it over with ASAP.  As soon as you have and begin your treatment plan, the sooner this will all be over.  You have a great attitude, and that's half of it.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Hello, I just stepped over from not diagnosed GmaFoley sagina

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 09:45PM dawn31337 wrote: I had AC and T, and never heard of the leukemia thing.  Listen to your medical team and not the BS you read on the Internet or on these boards.  Your oncologist has been to medical school, and chances are, you haven't.  You may have done research, but without a medical background, it is not likely you would be able to interpret what you have found considering your specific history. Emend works wonders.  I felt queasy a few times, but was never really sick.  If you are sick, call your oncologist, and s/he can give you something else.  There is no reason to be sick anymore.   Best of luck to you!!  You can and will get through this!
Posts.Title: AC and T chemo stella0926 dawn31337

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 08:08PM dawn31337 wrote: oh, i should add during my BLM operation sentinel nodes were negative, but they found one positive afterwards.  I didn't have the rest removed, as my BS said there is scar tissue and possible lymphedemia issues if they go back.  Also would have made me wait another 4-6 weeks to begin chemo...i thought that was 6 in one, half dozen in the other.  The chemo's supposed to kill whatever's left anyway. Don't be alarmed when you pee bright green, that's just the blue dye with your yellow urine :)
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 07:20PM dawn31337 wrote: Hi RC, I was diagnosed in mid Sept, and my first thought was to get them both removed.  I am 49, do smoke and drink, etc, I'm healthy but not athletic, weight in proportion to height.  I had the same options as you.  My family is very small and I make 100% of the women who have had BC.  I started thinking about lumpectomy, but then I found out I am triple negative, so I went with my first thought and had BLM on 10/15/10, with immediate reconstruction with tissue expanders.  I took off the week leading up to my surgery, rode my Harley a lot, and generally just had a good time.  Had a private goodbye to the boobies all nighter on Wednesday with a guy I date, and off to the OR on Friday.  I came home Saturday, and went back to work Monday (let me qualify that by saying I do IT work from home, desk job, talking on the phone and typing emails, etc).  Got my drains out I believe 10 days later.  They're kind of gross, but more of a nuisance than uncomfortable.  Sleeping was tough at first, but it was only 3 weeks ago tomorrow, and I'm getting used to not sleeping on my stomach.  The TE's are very hard, and you can see them under the skin and feel them. For me, the BLM was an absolute breeze.  I was shocked.  Part of the reason is when they remove all the breast tissue, they also cut the nerves, so there really isn't a lot of pain.  I had nipple sparing on one side and skin sparing on the other, so I'm missing a nipple for now.  Immediately post-op, by boobs didn't look half as bad as I thought they would.  I had my first TE fill yesterday, and that didn't hurt at all.  Had a date last night (with the big reveal!) and it went really well! BLM was right for me, but I'm not the expert a lot of the ladies here are.  DCIS is usually localized, right?  If you decide to go the BLM route, I hope my experience gives you some comfort and insight.   Yes, the whole process is frightening and unfair.  I have a goal to be done with my treatment and reconstruction by the end of May, which my Drs think is doable.  I see the oncologist tomorrow and will find out when I start chemo.  Try to keep a positive attitude.  If you expect the worst, that's what you get. Best of luck, and let me know what you decide! Dawn
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed rc778 rc778

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 08:18PM dawn31337 wrote: I'm with CoolBreeze.  Chemo was almost a non event.  It is in no way as horrible as you probably expect.  I was fortunate in that I work from home.  I had fatigue but no real sickness.  I was queasy a few times.  I worked full time and took off on chemo days, but in all honesty, if I had to get dressed and drive to work every day, that could have been an issue.  I did recover quickly and after 3 weeks I was feeling pretty much back to normal.  I think the hair loss was the worst part.  You don't look like yourself.  I had really pretty wigs and looked nice, but it was a constant reminder I was sick, even though I didn't feel that bad.  Best of luck to you.  A positive attitude does go a long way.
